featured.text: MOOCs first made waves in the fall of 2011, when Professor Sebastian Thrun from Stanford University opened his graduate-level artificial intelligence course up to any student anywhere, and 160,000 students in more than 190 countries signed up.
The students in Professor Smith’s classical Chinese class are required to _____
But the professor just returned it to me.
The 70-year-old professor sued the university for age _____, because his teaching contract had not been renewed.
The many awards that Professor Wang has won over the years are clear ______ that he is a distinguished scholar.

other.text: Some critics have said that MOOCs promote an unrealistic one-size-fits-all model of higher education and that there is no replacement for true dialogues between professors and their students.
2. Are the professors in the departments you plan to ___(28)___ into experts in their own fields? 3.
Professor Thrun has even envisioned a future in which there will only need to be 10 universities in the world.
The lack of social interaction among students and professors.
Perhaps the most striking thing about MOOCs, many of which are being taught by professors at prestigious universities, is that they’re free.
Michael has decided to _____ a career in physics and has set his mind on becoming a professor.

In addition to traditional course materials such as videos, readings, and problem sets, MOOCs provide interactive user forums that help build a community for the students, professors, and teaching assistants.
His father, __(19)__ always hoped that he would get a PhD and become a professor, __(20)__ with a scoff: “What is all this nonsense?!”
The overreliance on professors from prestigious universities.

definition.zh_def: 教授；大學或學院的高級教師。
definition.en_def: A teacher of the highest rank in a college or university.
definition.example: The professor gave an inspiring lecture on modern literature.
